content.description:
Climb the South face of

The Penguin

. A thin crack climbs through a bulge with some loose holds along the way.
content.protection: Small cams, from blue Metolius through .75 camalot. The anchor consists of slings (some old and some new) around the summit block.
content.location:
Located about 10 feet right of the bolted route called

The Penguin.

content.description:
A short face climb on the west face of

The Penguin

starting in the gully between the pinnacle and the

Tear Garden

wall. An optional hand sized cam could be placed getting up to the first bolt.
content.protection: An optional hand sized piece, one bolt, one pin, and one more bolt. The anchor consists of slings (some old and some new) around the summit block.
content.location: The obvious bolted line, facing the Tear Garden wall.

content.description:
Every year

Emperor

penguins overcome great obstacles in order to return to their breeding grounds. The march of the penguins is an arduous, dangerous, and difficult battle to maintain survival and continue life. While this route does not end at a penguin brothel, lets hope the trip to the top is nowhere near as perilous?

A deceptive route that climbs

The Penguin's

proud east-face. Steeper than it looks, this line follows the dead-center path of least resistance. Described as "difficult to read", curiosity will be most beneficial, as will balance and fitness. Expect steep face climbing with hidden pockets and edges.

Start in the obvious wide crack and climb to a shallow ledge, clip a bolt and prepare for the funk. Lean left of the right-side arete and mantle a sloping shelf. Continue straight up the face following the bolt line. Plenty of holds exist, but finding them seems to be the crux.
content.protection: Quick draws to a sling anchor. Optional #5 Camalot for the crack at the start.
content.location:
Found on the direct, east face of

The Penguin

. This is the only line w/ black bolts.
